L.HI: Oh first and most benevolent of Powers!
Sent from eternal splendors here on earth,
Against despotic pride, and rage, and lust,
To shield mankind, to rouse them to assert
The native rights and honor of their race!

P.HI: THE subject of the following Tragedy, which has never been acted or published, is purely fabulous. It has human nature, but no particular nation, or individual, for its ob∣ject. The author thinks this declaration neces∣sary, as it may prevent malignant criticism from imputing sentiments to him, which he abhors. He wishes to be thought, however ob∣scure, an advocate for liberty, on the most enlarged and liberal plan; but he is warrant∣ed, by history, in affirming, that true liberty may as effectually be destroyed by the machina∣tions of a party, as by the ambition of a single person. An aristocracy appears to him to be the most odious and oppressive of all modes of government, nor is it destroyed without the greatest difficulty; for that monster has many heads.

May the Citizens of this State continue to prize the generous system of liberty, which their virtue has established! As they have bravely repelled foreign usurpation, may they with equal success prevent domestic encroachment! Thus shall they not at some distant period, be com∣pelled to fly for refuge to monarchy, from a turbulent, oppressive and tyrannical aristocracy.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: 'TWAS weak; 'twas wrong; this turbulence forebodes
Some greater evil, and the King may soon
Repent his tame compliance.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: You are warm.
Your zeal, Otanes, hurries you beyond
The bounds of reason; but the people's voice,
The voice of millions in so just a cause,
Demands the monarch's ear, and should enforce
Conviction.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: Much I fear, their factious clamors
Will gain upon the easy King to grant
More insolent demands; then may we see
The sceptre wrested from the feeble hand
Of flexile majesty.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: You wrong the people.
They idolize their King; his better years,
They know, were spent amidst the rage of war,
To save them from the hated Persian yoke.
Heaven crown'd his valor with success, and now,
With filial piety and veneration,
They view his sacred head, hoary with age,
And bending with the weight of public cares
For Lydia's safety.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: Slightly they regard
His cares and valor; and for wealth and freedom
Repay him with the insolence of faction.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: Long since has Lydia graced with full reward
The actions of her chief; with fame, respect,
Obedience and a crown. Think not, I speak
With democratic zeal; with sacred awe
I venerate the hand, that sways the sceptre,
And bow before the delegate of Heaven.
His country's love, not wild ambition, rouz'd
His matchless valor; when the Persian fled,
And freedom, the reward of public virtue,
Benignly smil'd again, the warrior sought
His lov'd domestic ease, as if he scorn'd
That sceptre, which the fates had destin'd for him.
But Lydia, urg'd by civil discontent,
And mindful of her hero's long-tried worth,
Plac'd him reluctant on the throne, and grac'd
His honour'd brows with glory nobly earn'd.
And shall that people, whose all-giving hand
Whose matchless bounty—

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: Spare that argument;
I feel its utmost force. But grant, a King,
Best in his subjects' love, and fully warm'd
With grateful sentiments, to their desires
Should sacrifice his will, why should the people
Controul the father, and invade a right
The meanest hind enjoys. You know the cares,
That wring his aged heart and bow him down
More than the weight of years; the ills, that threaten
His son, his lov'd Olinthus.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: I have heard
The tale confusedly; but the Gods will never
Desert their image; virtue is their care,
And Dorus claims their patronage; his sun,
Which in its zenith shone with so much lustre,
Must set serene, unsullied with a cloud.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: I doubt it much. (aside.) Hard were their hearts indeed,
Who could, unmoved, behold the tears stream down
His furrow'd cheeks, whilst all in vain he pleaded
His former services, his present cares.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: Never, Otanes, shall we see again
So great a scene. The King is more than man.
He felt as man; but like a God resolv'd.
Soon as the rays of truth dispell'd the mist
Of weak paternal love, his frame grew larger,
As if some heavenly impulse swell'd his bosom.
His sparkling eyes shone with unequall'd lustre;
His voice imprinted awe; but when he bent
His knees, and rais'd his trembling hands to Heaven,
Imploring Jove to guide his wandering steps
Thro' the dark labyrinth of dreaded woes,
I melted, wept—They were not tears of sorrow;,
No, they were tears of joy, and, might I say it,
Of adoration.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: Still my heart forebodes,
Some sad disaster threats his close of life.
Hast thou not heard, that awful prodigies
Alarm the priests and awe the trembling city.
When they led forth, in all the pomp of prayer,
The sacrifice for Dorus' life and safety,
Th' ungovern'd victim rush'd among the crowd,
Fled thro' the streets, and with unequall'd swift∣ness,
Travers'd the plain, and has not since been seen.
In great Cybele's fane strange sounds were heard,
Like dying infants' cries, as if again
Old Saturn cruelly prepar'd to feast
On his own offspring. Every cheek is pale
With gloomy apprehension, and the priests
Tremble with sacred horror.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: To the Gods
Let us, Otanes, leave th' accomplishment
Of their decrees. It ill befits frail man,
To strive, with feeble eyes, to pierce the cloud
Of dark futurity. The Gods must crown
The virtuous man with never-fading bliss.
To check the haughty, to exalt the good,
But chiefly to instruct his son to rise
By the same steps to equal heights of virtue,
These should be Dorus' cares: Futurity
Belongs to Heaven.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: The People seem to dread
A war impending.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: They judge right, Otanes.
The Persian views our happy state with envy,
And meditates new chains.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: I know him loyal,
still the dread of rivalry may rouze
spark of envy. (aside) Dorus is grown old,
erspent with former toils. Occasion smiles
the young Prince. He now may prove the blood
om which he sprung, and emulate his fire.

nd guide their swords, quick as the lightning's speed
gainst their foes.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: In many a well-fought field.
is true, I've follow'd glory. But my tongue
ust not be boastful. If my arm has conquer'd,
have my full reward in Lydia's safety
And the King's smile. But could I see the Prince,
reat as his fire, when on yon blood-stain'd field,
( then was young) the Persians saw his sword
ame like a comet, threatening desolation,
ow would I bless the Gods and bid adieu
o arms glory, pleas'd to hear the crowd
dmire his gallant actions, far surpassing
My slender fame, and rivalling his father's.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: But hast thou seen the Prince in his retirement?

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: have, Otanes; and methought perceiv'd
The dawn of future glory. How I wish'd
To be Araspes thy much honour'd son.
The Prince doats on him. He with duteous care
Repays his master's love. One will, one spirit,
Actuate both. The chace is their delight.
How have I seen their ardent spirits rise,
Their youthful bosoms throb with fierce delight
When they have chac'd the stag, or rouz'd
With martial rage.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: These praises call the ears
Of transport down my cheek.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: Happy old man!
I once had such a son.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: Thou hast a daughter
Gentle and good, and blooming as the flowers,
Which nature scatters round with lavish hand.
Araspes shall supply the son you mourn,
Blest in Ismene's love.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: Thanks, good Otanes.
But I have doubts.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: What doubts? dost thou reject?—

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: No, your alliance has my warmest wishes.
My doubts are these: The little jealous God
Smiles at parental wisdom, and derides
The prudent plan design'd by sober age.
Love is the cordial drop, which sweetens life,
Without it all is bitterness and woe.
Ismene 's gentle; never yet have I
Controul'd her will. Whoever wins her heart,
Wins my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: OTANES.
SP.L: O! may Araspes view
charms with soft desire!

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: And may the God
love light up such flames in either heart,
warm'd my breast, when first my wond'ring eyes
held her mother! But the King approaches,
With other look, with other mien we have seen him
wering like Mars, the terror of the plain.

SP.SPEAKER: DORUS.
SP.L: , art thou here? Adrastus too?
near, and let me on your faithful bosoms
my wearied frame. Alas! I tremble.
let me rest a while.

SP.SPEAKER: ADRASTUS.
SP.L: Permit me, Dorus,
ask, honest zeal, whence flow those tears
ich stain thy manly cheek. I blush to see them.

SP.SPEAKER: DORUS.
SP.L: Well I knew
You wouldst condemn my weakness. But, Adras∣tus,
You little know'st the torments I endure.
